The chapter on samÄdhi in the introductory section, part 2: What is called the samÄdhi of luminous thought?

Just as a bhiká¹£u, having cultivated concentration and practiced it much, in one garden, two or three, up to ten gardens, with a pure mind pervades the practice with a mind of brightness and superiority, as a person's thoughts and recollections, this is called the thought of brightness.

Just as a bhiká¹£u, having cultivated concentration closely and practiced it much, if in one garden, two or three up to ten gardens, with a pure mind pervades the practice with a bright mind, as a real person thinks and recollects this thought, it is called the bright thought.
If this thought arises, abides, and ceases together with it, it is called the common bright thought-conception.

Just as a bhiká¹£u, having cultivated concentration closely and practiced it much, if all around the water and land, with a pure mind pervades the practice with a bright mind, as a real person thinks and recollects this thought, it is called the bright thought.

Just as a bhiká¹£u, having become intimate with and practiced much concentration, with the pure divine eye that surpasses human, sees beings' births and deaths, good color and bad color, good destinies and bad destinies, low and exalted.

This being, with the accomplishment of good bodily actions, verbal and mental actions, does not slander the sages, has right views, creates the karma of right bodily actions, and upon the dissolution of the body, after death, is reborn in the heavens or among humans.
Thus, with the pure divine eye that surpasses human, he sees beings' births and deaths, good color and bad color, good destinies and bad destinies, and knows that beings create karma.

Having cultivated this concentration, with the pure divine eye surpassing that of humans, one sees the birth and death of sentient beings and even knows the karma they have created. This is called the concentration of clear knowledge.

A bhiká¹£u contemplates impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self, and nirvana as tranquil, and attains concentration with a still mind.

Having attained concentration, he attains the first five noble faculties. Because he has attained the first five noble faculties, he correctly determines the superior and leaves the stage of ordinary beings, but has not yet attained the fruit of stream-entry. If he were to die in the middle, there is no such possibility.
If he has not yet attained the fruit of stream-entry, it is impossible for him to fall into the hells, the animal realm, or the realm of hungry ghosts.

If a bhiká¹£u, having closely attended and cultivated this samÄdhi much, attains uninterrupted progress toward the fruit of stream-entry, and if this samÄdhi ceases uninterruptedly after that, and he attains the fruit of stream-entry, this is called uninterrupted samÄdhi.

The mind relying on the thinking consciousness, the mind alone, the power of concentration, the enlightenment factor of concentration, and right concentration, are called the faculty of concentration.
What is the power of concentration?
The faculty of concentration is called the power of concentration.
What is the enlightenment factor of concentration?
The power of concentration is called the enlightenment factor of concentration.
What is right concentration?
If concentration is wholesome, in accordance with the truth, and not contrary to it, it is called right concentration.
What is wrong concentration?
If concentration is unwholesome, not in accordance with the truth, and contrary to it, it is called wrong concentration.
What is noble concentration?
If concentration is without outflows, it is called noble concentration.
What is non-noble concentration?
If concentration has outflows, it is called non-noble concentration.
What is concentration with outflows?
If concentration is defiled, it is called concentration with outflows.
What is concentration without outflows?
If concentration is undefiled, it is called concentration without outflows.

If concentration has craving, it is called defiled concentration.

If a samÄdhi definitely has no seeking, it is called a samÄdhi without defilements.

If a samÄdhi definitely has something to take, it is called a samÄdhi with seeking.

If a samÄdhi definitely has nothing to take, it is called a samÄdhi without seeking.

If a samÄdhi has something to take, it is called a samÄdhi with something to take.

If a samÄdhi has nothing to take, it is called a samÄdhi without something to take.

If a samÄdhi has something superior, it is called a samÄdhi with something.

If a samÄdhi has nothing superior, it is called a samÄdhi without something.

If a samÄdhi has something to take, it is called a samÄdhi with something superior.

If a samÄdhi does not take, it is called a samÄdhi without something superior.
Moreover, if a samÄdhi has other samÄdhis that are superior and wonderful, it is called a samÄdhi with something superior.
If there is no other samÄdhi that surpasses it, it is called the samÄdhi of no superiority.

If a samÄdhi is excluded from the above, it is called the samÄdhi of no superiority.
What is the samÄdhi of feeling?
If a samÄdhi is internal, it is called the samÄdhi of feeling.

If a samÄdhi is external, it is called the samÄdhi of not feeling.

If a samÄdhi is feeling, it is called the internal samÄdhi.

What is concentration that is not attained with certainty?

I should cultivate desire and effort, and practice them extensively.
If a bhiká¹£u cultivates desire and effort, and practices them extensively, he should strive to attain concentration.
If he attains concentration in this way, this is called attaining concentration without aspiration.

I should cultivate this concentration extensively, so that I can attain concentration through power, respect, and mastery.
If a bhiká¹£u cultivates concentration extensively, so that he can attain concentration through power, respect, and mastery,
if he attains concentration in this way, this is called attaining concentration without tranquility and aspiration.
